title: Ted Holdcroft
text:
Hugh Edward Holdcroft (c. 1882 – 4 February 1952) was an <a href="English%20people">English</a> <a href="Association%20football">footballer</a> who played in the <a href="English%20Football%20League">Football League</a> for <a href="Port%20Vale%20F.C.">Burslem Port Vale</a> and <a href="Stoke%20City%20F.C.">Stoke</a> in the early 1900s.
Playing career.
Holdcroft joined <a href="Port%20Vale%20F.C.">Burslem Port Vale</a> in October 1901. His debut came at centre-half in a goalless draw with <a href="Preston%20North%20End%20F.C.">Preston North End</a> at the <a href="Athletic%20Ground%20%28Cobridge%29">Athletic Ground</a> on 8 September 1902. He scored his first goal in the <a href="English%20Football%20League">Football League</a> on 25 October, converting a penalty in a 3–3 draw with <a href="Burnley%20F.C.">Burnley</a> at <a href="Turf%20Moor">Turf Moor</a>. He became a first team regular for the <a href="Football%20League%20Second%20Division">Second Division</a> side from the next month until he suffered a <a href="toe">toe</a> injury in February 1903 and transferred to <a href="Potteries%20derby">local rivals</a> <a href="Stoke%20City%20F.C.">Stoke</a> in March 1903. At £500 this was a <a href="List%20of%20Stoke%20City%20F.C.%20records%20and%20statistics">club record</a> for Stoke.
Holdcroft was converted into a <a href="Forward%20%28association%20football%29">centre forward</a> at the <a href="Victoria%20Ground">Victoria Ground</a> with mixed success. He hit two goals in a 5–2 win over <a href="Liverpool%20F.C.">Liverpool</a> on 17 October 1903, and opened the <a href="1905%E2%80%9306%20Stoke%20F.C.%20season">1905–06</a> season with a goal in each of the first three <a href="Football%20League%20First%20Division">First Division</a> games, but other than these highlights he proved to be far from a natural goalscorer and in three seasons he scored 11 goals in 44 appearances. After retiring due to an ankle injury and later suffering a serious illness that prevented him finding a job, Vale and Stoke held a benefit match on his behalf on 29 April 1907; the game finished 1–1. This would prove to be Burslem Port Vale's final ever match, as the club were dissolved, only to re-emerge later in the year when Cobridge Church renamed themselves Port Vale F.C.
